pages.title: Howard Masur
pages.text:
{{short description|American mathematician}}
[[File:Masur howard.jpg|thumb|Howard Masur, in [[Oberwolfach]] (2014).]]

'''Howard Alan Masur''' is an [[Americans|American]] [[mathematician]] who works on [[topology]], [[geometry]] and [[combinatorial group theory]].<ref>[http://math.uchicago.edu/~masur/ Howard Masur at the University of Chicago]</ref><ref>[http://math.uchicago.edu/~chicagotopology/ First Chicago Summer School in Geometry and Topology]</ref>

The [[Hubbard–Masur theorem]] is named after Masur and [[John H. Hubbard]].<ref>R. A. Wentworth, "[http://www.math.umd.edu/~raw/papers/gardiner.pdf Energy of Harmonic Maps and Gardiner’s Formula]"</ref> Masur was an invited speaker at the 1994 [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in [[Zürich]].<ref>[http://www.mathunion.org/db/ICM/Speakers/SortedByCongress.php ICM Plenary and Invited Speakers since 1897]</ref> and is a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]</ref>

Along with [[Yair Minsky]], Masur is one of the pioneers of the study of [[curve complex]] geometry.<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Benson Farb]]|title=Problems on Mapping Class Groups and Related Topics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uiqDbaQRr7IC&pg=PA140|year=2006|publisher=[[American Mathematical Society]]|isbn=978-0-8218-3838-9|page=140}}</ref> He also contributed to the understanding of the convergence of geodesic rays in [[Teichmüller theory]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Athanase Papadopoulos|title=Handbook of Teichmüller Theory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PSL1SDKRtPcC&pg=PA115|year=2007|publisher=[[European Mathematical Society]]|isbn=978-3-03719-029-6|page=115}}</ref>

In 2009, a conference of mathematicians honored Masur's 60th birthday in [[France]].<ref>[http://www.cpt.univ-mrs.fr/~masur60/ "Dynamics and Geometry of Teichmuller Space (honoring the 60th birthday of Howard Masur). Luminy, France. June 18-20, 2009."]</ref>

Masur was a Ph.D. student of [[Albert Marden]] at the [[University of Minnesota-Minneapolis]].<ref>[http://genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=2458 Mathematics Genealogy Project]</ref>

==Selected papers==
*{{cite journal|author=Howard Masur|title=Interval exchange transformations and measured foliations|journal=[[Annals of Mathematics]]|year=1982|volume=115|issue=1|pages=169–200|doi=10.2307/1971341}}
*{{cite journal|author=Howard Masur|title=On a class of geodesics in Teichmuller space|journal=Annals of Mathematics|year=1975|volume=102|issue=2|pages=205–221|doi=10.2307/1971031}}

'''Émile Léonard Mathieu''' ({{IPA-fr|matjø|lang}}; 15 May 1835, [[Metz]] – 19 October 1890, [[Nancy, France|Nancy]]) was a [[France|French]] [[mathematician]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Duhem, P.|authorlink=Pierre Duhem|title=Émile Mathieu, his life and works|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|year=1892|volume=1|issue=7|pages=156–168|mr=1557168|doi=10.1090/s0002-9904-1892-00067-5}}</ref> He is known for his work in [[group theory]] and [[mathematical physics]]. He has given his name to the [[Mathieu function]]s, [[Mathieu group]]s and [[Mathieu transformation]]. He authored a treatise of mathematical physics in 6 volumes.
Volume 1 is an exposition of the techniques to solve the [[differential equations]] of mathematical physics,
and contains an account of the applications of [[Mathieu functions]] to [[electrostatics]].
Volume 2 deals with [[capillarity]]. Volumes 3 and 4 deal with [[electrostatics]] and [[magnetostatics]].
Volume 5 deals with [[electrodynamics]], and volume 6 with [[Elasticity (physics)|elasticity]]. The [[asteroid]] [[27947 Emilemathieu]] was named in his honour.

==Books by Émile Mathieu==

* [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k99736x.r=Dynamique+Analytique.langFR Dynamique Analytique] (Gauthier-Villars, 1878)

pages.title: John McKay (mathematician)
pages.text:
{{short description|Mathematician}}
{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}}
'''John K. S. McKay''' (born 18 November 1939, [[Kent]]){{cn|date=April 2019}} is a dual British/Canadian citizen, a [[mathematics|mathematician]] at [[Concordia University (Quebec)|Concordia University]], known for his discovery of [[monstrous moonshine]], his joint construction of some [[sporadic simple group]]s, for the [[Mckay conjecture]] in representation theory, and for the [[McKay correspondence]] relating certain [[finite group]]s to [[Lie group]]s.

McKay earned his Bachelor and Diploma in 1961 and 1962 at the [[University of Manchester]], and his [[Ph.D.]]<ref>{{Cite journal|date=1971|others=Munn, W.D., Michaelson, S.|title=Computing with finite groups|url=http://hdl.handle.net/1842/6615|language=en}}</ref> in 1971 from the [[University of Edinburgh]].<ref name=phd>{{MathGenealogy|id=94551}}</ref>
Since 1974 he works at Concordia University, since 1979 as a professor in Computer Science.

He was elected a fellow of the [[Royal Society of Canada]] in 2000, and won the 2003 [[CRM-Fields-PIMS prize]].

In April 2007 a Joint Conference was organised by the [[Université de Montréal]] and Concordia University honouring four decades of the work of John McKay.

pages.title: George Abram Miller
pages.text:
{{Infobox scientist
| name        = George A. Miller
| image       = George A Miller.jpg
| image_size  = 
| alt         = 
| caption     = 
| birth_date  = {{birth date |1863|7|31|mf=y}}
| birth_place = Lynnville, [[Lehigh County, Pennsylvania]]
| death_date  = {{death date and age |1951|2|10 |1863|7|31|mf=y}}
| death_place = [[Urbana, Illinois]]
| nationality = [[United States|American]]
| fields      = [[Mathematics]]
| workplaces  = [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|University of Illinois]]
| alma_mater  = [[Cumberland University]]
| doctoral_advisor = [[Frank Nelson Cole]] <!--(or  | doctoral_advisors = )-->
| doctoral_students = [[Henry Louis Rietz]]
| known_for   = 
| awards      = 
}}

'''George Abram Miller''' (31 July 1863 – 10 February 1951) was an early [[group theory|group theorist]].

At age 17 Miller began school-teaching to raise funds for higher education. In 1882 he entered Franklin and Marshall Academy, and progressed to [[Muhlenberg College]] in 1884. He received his B.A. in 1887 and M.A. in 1890. While a graduate student, Miller was Principal of schools in [[Greeley, Kansas]] and then professor of mathematics as [[Eureka College]] in Eureka, Illinois. He corresponded with [[Cumberland University]] in Lebanon, Tennessee for his Ph.D. in 1892. He then joined [[Frank Nelson Cole]] at [[University of Michigan]] and began to study [[group (mathematics)|group]]s. In 1895 he went to Europe where he heard [[Sophus Lie]] lecture at Leipzig and [[Camille Jordan]] at Paris. In 1897 he went to [[Cornell University]] as an assistant professor, and in 1901 to [[Stanford University]] as associate professor. In 1906 he went to [[University of Illinois]] where he taught until retirement in 1931.<ref name=HRB>[[Henry Roy Brahana]] (1957) {{Biographical Memoirs|miller-george-a}}</ref>

Miller helped in the enumeration of [[finite group]]s of degree 8, 9, and 10. [[Arthur Cayley]] had listed 198 groups of degree 8 in 1891, and Miller found two more making the total 200 in 1893. Camille Jordan had given a list for degree 9 in 1872, re-examined by Cole, and brought up to 258 groups by Miller. In 1894 Miller produced a list of 294 intransitive groups of degree 10. In consequence, the Academy of Science of Cracow awarded a prize and "Miller came to prominence in the mathematical world abruptly."<ref name=HRB/>

Miller was president of the [[Mathematical Association of America]] 1921–1922<ref>[http://www.maa.org/history/presidents/miller.html MAA presidents: George Abram Miller]</ref> and gave a [[plenary address at the International Congress of Mathematicians]] in 1924 in Toronto.<ref>{{cite book|author=Miller, G. A.|chapter=History of several fundamental mathematical concepts|title=''In:'' Proceedings of the International Congress of Mathematicians in Toronto, August 11–16. 1924|volume=vol. 2|pages=959–968}}</ref> Miller's ''Collected Works'' were edited by [[Henry Roy Brahana]] and published by [[University of Illinois Press]], the first two volumes appearing in 1935 and 1939.<ref>J.S. Frame (1940) [http://www.ams.org/mathscinet/pdf/256.pdf Review of ''Collected Works of George Abram Miller''] in [[Mathematical Reviews]]</ref> The final three volumes were published in 1946, 1955, and 1959. His doctoral students include [[Henry Louis Rietz|H. L. Rietz]].

==Publications==
* 1892: [https://books.google.com/books?id=SZ0KAAAAYAAJ An introduction to the study of Determinants, with examples and applications].
* 1905: ''Groups of subtraction and division''.
* 1908: "On the multiple holomorphs of a group", [[Mathematische Annalen]] 66(1): 133-142
* 1911: "Abstract definitions of all the substitution groups whose degrees do not exceed seven", [[American Journal of Mathematics]] 
* 1911: ''The Algebraic Equation''
* 1916: (with [[H. F. Blichfeldt]], & [[L. E. Dickson]]) [http://quod.lib.umich.edu/u/umhistmath/ACM6867.0001.001?view=toc ''Theory and Application of Finite Groups''] from [[University of Michigan]] Historical Math Collection, original publisher: [[John Wiley & Sons]].
* 1916: [https://books.google.com/books?id=e1UuAAAAYAAJ Historical Introduction to Mathematical Literature] from [[Cornell University]] Historical Math Monographs, original publisher [[Macmillan Publishers]].<ref>[[G. B. Mathews]] (1917) [http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v98/n2464/pdf/098387a0.pdf Review: ''A Historical Introduction to the Mathematical Literature''] from [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] 98:387 (#2464)</ref>
* 1947: "An Eleventh Lesson in the History of Mathematics", [[Mathematics Magazine]] 21(1): 48-55.

pages.title: Mahan Mj
pages.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Mahan Mj |image =Replace_this_image_male.svg |image_size = 150px |caption = Mahan Mitra |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[India]]n |field = [[Mathematics]] |work_institutions = [[Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]] |alma_mater = [[Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur]]
[[University of California, Berkeley]] |doctoral_advisor = [[Andrew Casson]] |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = [[Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Award]] Infosys Prize 2015 for Mathematical Sciences |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Mahan Mj''' (born Mahan Mitra ([[Bengali language|Bengali]]: মহান মিত্র), 5 April 1968 {{cite web | url= http://ssbprize.gov.in/content/Detail.aspx?AID=359}}), also known as '''Mahan Maharaj''' and '''Swami Vidyanathananda''', is an Indian [[mathematician]] and monk of the [[Ramakrishna Order]]. He is currently Professor of Mathematics at the [[Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]] in [[Mumbai]]. He is a recipient of the 2011 [[Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Award]] in [[Mathematical sciences|Mathematical Sciences]].http://www.csir.res.in/external/heads/career/award/2011/ssb2011_awardees.pdf{{cite news|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/generalnewsfeed/news/11-scientists-selected-for-shanti-swarup-bhatnagar-award/836081.html |title=11 scientists selected for Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar award |date=26 September 2011 |agency=[[CNN-IBN|IBN Live]] |accessdate=20 December 2011 |author=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]] |location=[[New Delhi]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104061539/http://ibnlive.in.com/generalnewsfeed/news/11-scientists-selected-for-shanti-swarup-bhatnagar-award/836081.html |archivedate=4 January 2012 |df= }} and the [[Infosys Prize]] 2015 for Mathematical Sciences.http://www.infosys-science-foundation.com/prize/laureates/2015/index.asp He is best known for his work in [[hyperbolic geometry]], [[geometric group theory]], [[low-dimensional topology]] and [[complex geometry]]. == Early education == Mahan Mitra studied at [[St. Xavier's Collegiate School]], [[Calcutta]], till Class XII. He then entered the [[Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur]], with an AIR (All India Rank) rank of 67 in the Joint Entrance Examination, where he initially chose to study [[electrical engineering]] but later switched to [[mathematics]]. He graduated with a Masters in mathematics from IIT Kanpur in 1992.{{cite web | url=http://www.iitk.ac.in/dord/institutelecture/Mahan%20MJ%20_14-11-2011__1.pdf | title=Institute Lecture: What is hyperbolic geometry? | publisher=[[IIT Kanpur]] | accessdate=11 January 2013}} == Career == Mahan Mitra joined the [[Ph.D.]] program in mathematics at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], with [[Andrew Casson]] as his advisor.{{cite web|url=http://genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=24444|title=The Mathematics Genealogy Project - Andrew Casson|work=nodak.edu}} He received the [[Earle C. Anthony]] Fellowship, U.C. Berkeley in 1992–1993 and the prestigious [[Sloan Fellowship]] for 1996–1997. After earning a doctorate from U.C. Berkeley in 1997, he worked briefly at the [[Institute of Mathematical Sciences, Chennai]] in 1998. Spiritually inclined, he joined the [[Ramakrishna Math]] as a renunciate upon being impressed by the life and work of the Vedantic philosopher [[Ramakrishna Paramahansa]]. His initial name was Brahmachari BrahmaChaitanya. He was renamed as Swami Vidyanathananda after receiving his ochre robe in 2008.{{cite web | url= http://www.infosys-science-foundation.com/prize/laureates/2015/mahan-maharaj.asp}} Swami Vidyanathananda is a monk at the order's headquarters at Belur Math. He was Professor of Mathematics and Dean of Research at the [[Ramakrishna Mission Vivekananda University]] till 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Vidyanathananda-the-wizard-who-became-a-monk/articleshow/10626461.cms|title=Vidyanathananda, the wizard who became a monk - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-04-15}} He is currently Professor of Mathematics at the [[Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]], [[Mumbai]].http://www.math.tifr.res.in/people/faculty.php He has widely published and presented his research in the area of [[hyperbolic manifold]]s and [[Ending lamination theorem|ending lamination]] spaces. His most notable work is the proof of existence of [[Cannon–Thurston map]]s.http://annals.math.princeton.edu/2014/179-1/p01{{cite journal | doi=10.1007/s00039-014-0263-x | volume=24 | title=Ending Laminations and Cannon–Thurston Maps | journal=[[Geometric and Functional Analysis]] | pages=297–321| arxiv=math/0701725 |year = 2014|last1 = Mj|first1 = Mahan}} This led to the resolution of the conjecture that connected limit sets of finitely generated [[Kleinian group]]s are locally connected. He is also the author of a book titled ''Maps on boundaries of hyperbolic metric spaces''.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Maps_on_boundaries_of_hyperbolic_metric.html?id=4-2iHwAACAAJ | title=Maps on boundaries of hyperbolic metric spaces | publisher=[[University of California, Berkeley]] | author=Mitra, Mahan | year=1997 | location= | isbn=978-0591-52738-4}} Mj was an [[List of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers#2018, Rio de Janeiro|invited speaker]] at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in 2018 in [[Rio de Janeiro]]. == Personality == Mahan Maharaj, as he is known to his students and colleagues, is fluent in English, Hindi and Bengali. He also knows a bit of Tamil, learnt from his stay in southern part of India at [[Institute of Mathematical Sciences, Chennai|IMSc]]. He has been quoted as saying "I am enjoying being a monk as much as I enjoy my mathematics".{{cite news | url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/ml.asp?Ref=VE9JS00vMjAxMS8xMC8yOCNBcjAwMjAx | work=[[The Times Of India]] | last=Pandey | first=Jhimli Mukherjee | title=RKM monk wins country’s top math award | date=28 October 2011 | location=[[Kolkata]] | accessdate=29 January 2013}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == *{{MathGenealogy |id=31504}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110712202255/http://www.rkmvu.ac.in/intro/academics/matsc_website/mahan/index rkmvu.ac.in] *[http://gonitsora.com/the-monk-who-is-sold-on-geometry-an-interview-with-mahan-maharaj/ The Monk Who is Sold on Geometry] {{SSBPST recipients in Mathematical Science}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mj, Mahan}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur alumni]] [[Category:20th-century Indian mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century Indian mathematicians]] [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Monks of the Ramakrishna Mission]] [[Category:Topologists]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley alumni]] [[Category:Group theorists]] [[Category:Tata Institute of Fundamental Research faculty]]

pages.title: Horace Yomishi Mochizuki
pages.text:
'''Horace Yomishi Mochizuki''' (18 May 1937 – 9 June 1989) was an American mathematician known for his contributions to [[group theory]]. Mochizuki received a special award from the [[National Science Foundation]] for his work on the [[Burnside problem]].

== Biography ==
Mochizuki was born in California on 18 May 1937 from parents of Japanese ancestry.<ref name="Bachmuth 1991">{{cite book|last=Bachmuth|first=Seymour|last2=Millett|first2=Kenneth|date=1991|last3=Robertson|first3=James|chapter=Horace Y Mochizuki: In Memoriam|chapter-url=http://texts.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb4p30063r;NAAN=13030&doc.view=frames&chunk.id=div00038&toc.depth=1&toc.id=&brand=calisphere |title=Groups St Andrews 1989|pages=38–45|publisher=Cambridge University Press|language=en|doi=10.1017/cbo9780511721236.006|isbn=978-0-511-72123-6}}</ref> Following the [[Empire of Japan|Imperial Japan]]'s [[attack on Pearl Harbor]], President Roosevelt authorized on 19 February 1942 the deportation and internment of [[Japanese Americans]] with [[Executive Order 9066]] which allowed regional military commanders to designate "military areas" from which "any or all persons may be excluded". This authority was used to declare that all people of Japanese ancestry were excluded from the West Coast, including all of [[California]] and parts of [[Oregon]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], and [[Arizona]], except for those in government camps. Mochizuki was interned with his family in the [[Jerome War Relocation Center]] in Arkansas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oac.cdlib.org/ark:/13030/ft158003p8/?brand=oac4|title=Two young pre-school students play in the sand box at the Jerome Center grade school. Left, Sei Asaki; right, Horace Mochizuki. (Japanese Americans – Evacuation and relocation, 1942–1945 – Photographs)|last=Parker|first=Tom|date=10 March 1943|website=Online Archive of California|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-29}}</ref> After World War II, the family moved back to [[Madera, California]].

Mochizuki received his doctoral degree from the [[University of Washington]] with a dissertation work entitled "Finitistic homological dimensions and duality theory for rings".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=28124|title=Horace Mochizuki – The Mathematics Genealogy Project|website=www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu|access-date=2018-09-29}}</ref> He began teaching at [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] in 1965.<ref name="Fitzsimons 1989">{{Cite news|url=https://alexandria.ucsb.edu/downloads/br86b467f|title=Math Professor Dies, wife’s Death Follows|last=Fitzsimons|first=Matt|date=26 June 1989|work=Daily News|access-date=}}</ref>  Mochizuki passed away on 9 June 1989 from a cancer of pancreas.<ref name="Fitzsimons 1989" />

== Work ==
At the beginning of his academic career, Mochizuki's worked on [[ring theory]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mochizuki|first=Horace|date=1965|title=Finitistic global dimension for rings.|url=https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.pjm/1102996006|journal=Pacific Journal of Mathematics|language=en|volume=15|issue=1|pages=249–258|issn=0030-8730|doi=10.2140/pjm.1965.15.249}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mochizuki|first=H. Y.|date=1965|title=On the Double Commutator Algebra of QF-3 Algebras|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/nagoya-mathematical-journal/article/on-the-double-commutator-algebra-of-qf3-algebras/8C7C8FEC602E9F76F79053658CF7F375|journal=Nagoya Mathematical Journal|language=en|volume=25|pages=221–230|doi=10.1017/S0027763000011557|issn=0027-7630|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wu|first=L. E. T.|last2=Mochizuki|first2=H. Y.|last3=Jans|first3=J. P.|date=1966|title=A characterization of QF-3 rings|url=https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.nmj/1118801608|journal=Nagoya Mathematical Journal|language=en|volume=27|issue=Part|pages=7–13|issn=0027-7630|via=|doi=10.1017/S0027763000011806}}</ref> He started to cooperate with Seymour Bachmuth on [[group theory]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bachmuth|first=S.|last2=Mochizuki|first2=H. Y.|date=1966|title=Cyclotomic ideals in group rings|url=https://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1966-72-06/S0002-9904-1966-11623-3/|journal=Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society|language=en-US|volume=72|issue=6|pages=1018–1021|doi=10.1090/S0002-9904-1966-11623-3|issn=0002-9904|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bachmuth|first=S.|last2=Mochizuki|first2=H. Y.|date=1967|title=Automorphisms of a class of metabelian groups. II|url=https://www.ams.org/journals/tran/1967-127-02/S0002-9947-1967-0213437-6/|journal=Transactions of the American Mathematical Society|language=en-US|volume=127|issue=2|pages=294|doi=10.1090/S0002-9947-1967-0213437-6|issn=0002-9947|via=}}</ref><ref name="Mochizuki 1974">{{Citation|last=Mochizuki|first=Horace Y.|date=1974|pages=499–503|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|language=en|doi=10.1007/bfb0065206|isbn=978-3-540-06845-7|title=Proceedings of the Second International Conference on the Theory of Groups|volume=372|series=Lecture Notes in Mathematics|chapter=On groups of exponent four: A criterion for nonsolvability}}</ref> For his work on [[Burnside problem|Burnside groups]], Mochizuki received a special award from the [[National Science Foundation]] for "projects of high scientific merit involving scientists with a record of outstanding research accomplishments..."<ref name="Bachmuth 1991" /><ref name="Mochizuki 1974" />

Mochizuki is known for a non-commutative version of "Kolchin's Theorem" that solved a theorem of [[Irving Kaplansky|Ivan Kaplansky]] and for his work on [[Automorphism group of a free group|automorphism groups]] with Bachmuth.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mochizuki|first=H. Y.|date=1978|title=Unipotent matrix groups over division rings|url=https://cms.math.ca/openaccess/cmb/v21/cmb1978v21.0249-0250.pdf|journal=Canadian Mathematical Bulletin|volume=21|issue=2|pages=249–250|doi=10.4153/cmb-1978-043-2|issn=1496-4287|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Kaplansky|first=Irving|date=1977|chapter-url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/B9780120805501500226|pages=233–237|publisher=Elsevier|doi=10.1016/b978-0-12-080550-1.50022-6|isbn=978-0-12-080550-1|access-date=2018-09-29|title=Contributions to Algebra|chapter=The Engel–Kolchin theorem revisited}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bachmuth|first=S.|last2=Mochizuki|first2=H. Y.|date=1975|title=Automorphisms of solvable groups|url=https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.bams/1183536418|journal=Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society|language=EN|volume=81|issue=2|pages=420–422|issn=0002-9904|via=|doi=10.1090/S0002-9904-1975-13767-0}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=1978-11-01|title=IA-automorphisms of the free metabelian group of rank 3|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0021869378901941|journal=Journal of Algebra|language=en|volume=55|issue=1|pages=106–115|doi=10.1016/0021-8693(78)90194-1|issn=0021-8693|last1=Bachmuth|first1=Seymour|last2=Mochizuki|first2=Horace Y.}}</ref>
